articles.headline: As Brazil Crashes Out, the Magic Appears to Be Gone, Too
articles.snippet: Belgium scored twice in the first half as Brazil’s run at the World Cup ended in stunned silence on Friday, 2-1.
articles.abstract: Belgium scored twice in the first half as Brazil’s run at the World Cup ended in stunned silence on Friday, 2-1.
articles.lead_paragraph: KAZAN, Russia — It is a fine line between respect and deference, and in the days before they came face to face with Brazil, Belgium’s players and staff did all they could to navigate it.

articles.headline: When She Earns More: As Roles Shift, Old Ideas on Who Pays the Bills Persist
articles.snippet: Gender dynamics have become much more egalitarian over the past half-century, but certain attitudes may endure when it comes to men, women and money.
articles.abstract: Gender dynamics have become much more egalitarian over the past half-century, but certain attitudes may endure when it comes to men, women and money.
articles.lead_paragraph: For most of the 12 years of Nick and Natalie Foy’s marriage, Ms. Foy has been the primary breadwinner.

articles.headline: Trump Starts a Trade War, but the Path to Success Remains Unclear
articles.snippet: President Trump has said that trade wars are “easy to win,” but the question is whether he has a plan to achieve the results he wants.
articles.abstract: President Trump has said that trade wars are “easy to win,” but the question is whether he has a plan to achieve the results he wants.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and China hit each other with punishing tariffs on Friday as the two nations tipped into a long-feared trade war that is only expected to escalate.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson and Neil Irwin

articles.headline: Jim Jordan Is Defiant as Allegations Mount, and Supporters Point to ‘Deep State’
articles.snippet: The Ohio congressman insists he didn’t know that wrestlers on a college team he coached were being abused, and backers say he is the victim of conspirators who are trying to bring down the president.
articles.abstract: The Ohio congressman insists he didn’t know that wrestlers on a college team he coached were being abused, and backers say he is the victim of conspirators who are trying to bring down the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Representative Jim Jordan is facing the kind of slowly percolating scandal that would bring down other politicians in other times, as new accusers step forward by the day to say the wrestling coach turned politician was aware of sexual misconduct at Ohio State University but did nothing to stop it.

articles.headline: North Korea Criticizes ‘Gangster-Like’ U.S. Attitude After Talks With Mike Pompeo
articles.snippet: North Korea’s Foreign Ministry accused the Trump administration of pushing a “gangster-like demand for denuclearization.” But Secretary of State Mike Pompeo called the talks “productive.”
articles.abstract: North Korea’s Foreign Ministry accused the Trump administration of pushing a “gangster-like demand for denuclearization.” But Secretary of State Mike Pompeo called the talks “productive.”
articles.lead_paragraph: PYONGYANG, North Korea — North Korea accused the Trump administration on Saturday of pushing a “unilateral and gangster-like demand for denuclearization” and called it “deeply regrettable,” hours after Secretary of State Mike Pompeo said his two days of talks in the North Korean capital were “productive.”
articles.byline: By Gardiner Harris and Choe Sang-Hun

articles.headline: Oprah, Is That You? On Social Media, the Answer Is Often No.
articles.snippet: The sheer volume of fake Facebook and Instagram accounts that pose as celebrities is bringing real-life headaches to those public figures, including Oprah Winfrey.
articles.abstract: The sheer volume of fake Facebook and Instagram accounts that pose as celebrities is bringing real-life headaches to those public figures, including Oprah Winfrey.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Kip Moore, a country music singer-songwriter with hits like “Beer Money” and “Hey Pretty Girl,” has had some disturbing experiences with fans lately.

articles.headline: High-Skilled White-Collar Work? Machines Can Do That, Too
articles.snippet: Few jobs would appear less prone to automation than fashion industry taste-making. But artificial intelligence is undeterred.
articles.abstract: Few jobs would appear less prone to automation than fashion industry taste-making. But artificial intelligence is undeterred.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the best-selling T-shirts for the Indian e-commerce site Myntra is an olive, blue and yellow colorblocked design. It was conceived not by a human but by a computer algorithm — or rather two algorithms.

articles.headline: England Takes Another Step Toward Bringing ‘It’ Home
articles.snippet: The team advances to the World Cup semifinals for the first time since 1990 with a 2-0 victory over Sweden that was convincing, if not overly compelling.
articles.abstract: The team advances to the World Cup semifinals for the first time since 1990 with a 2-0 victory over Sweden that was convincing, if not overly compelling.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAMARA, Russia — There was little here to please the aesthetes, nothing much to arouse the adrenaline junkies.

articles.headline: This Italian Town Once Welcomed Migrants. Now, It’s a Symbol for Right-Wing Politics
articles.snippet: Macerata once had a reputation for tolerance. But the killing of a woman and a revenge shooting made the Italian town a symbol of rising right-wing politics.
articles.abstract: Macerata once had a reputation for tolerance. But the killing of a woman and a revenge shooting made the Italian town a symbol of rising right-wing politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: MACERATA, Italy — At the end of his shooting rampage as the police closed in, Luca Traini climbed the steps of a Fascist-era monument, wrapped himself in an Italian flag and straightened his arm in a Fascist salute.

articles.headline: Russia Finally Falls, Leaving a Trail of Admirers and Doubters
articles.snippet: Russia and Croatia had advanced to the quarterfinals through a victory in a penalty shootout. And on Saturday, both teams endured one again, with Russia finally falling short.
articles.abstract: Russia and Croatia had advanced to the quarterfinals through a victory in a penalty shootout. And on Saturday, both teams endured one again, with Russia finally falling short.
articles.lead_paragraph: SOCHI, Russia — It was only a couple of minutes to midnight, and Miroslav Romaschenko did not want to leave. As Croatia’s players bounced around in ecstasy and as Russia’s collapsed, disconsolate, onto their backs, the losing team’s assistant manager sat down, frozen in place on the Fisht Stadium’s turf.

articles.headline: ‘It’s a Terrible Vote’: Red-State Democrats Face an Agonizing Supreme Court Choice
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court votes by a handful of Senate Democrats from Republican states could have broad ramifications for their party, its leadership and its core voters.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court votes by a handful of Senate Democrats from Republican states could have broad ramifications for their party, its leadership and its core voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democratic senators running for re-election in Trump Country face an agonizing choice over President Trump’s coming Supreme Court nominee: Vote to confirm the pick and risk demoralizing Democratic voters ahead of the midterm elections, or stick with the party and possibly sacrifice their own seats — and any chance at a Democratic majority in 2019.

articles.headline: Trump ‘Very Close’ to Supreme Court Decision, but May Wait Till Final Hours
articles.snippet: President Trump spent the weekend soliciting opinions from dozens of people about what he should do, but said that “you can’t go wrong” with any of his four finalists.
articles.abstract: President Trump spent the weekend soliciting opinions from dozens of people about what he should do, but said that “you can’t go wrong” with any of his four finalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY HEIGHTS, N.J. — President Trump sought to mine a last bit of drama from his decision on a Supreme Court nominee on Sunday, saying he might need to extend the process well into Monday, just hours before he is scheduled to announce the pick in a prime-time address.
articles.byline: By Maggie Haberman, Adam Liptak and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Republicans and Democrats Face Leadership Struggles as House Returns
articles.snippet: There is an unsettled situation in the House, where neither party is sure of its leadership and no one knows who will be in control.
articles.abstract: There is an unsettled situation in the House, where neither party is sure of its leadership and no one knows who will be in control.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House returns from its July Fourth recess this week in a state of remarkable uncertainty, with both Democrats and Republicans facing open questions about their leaders’ futures and neither party sure about which will be in control after November’s elections.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Fandos and Thomas Kaplan

articles.headline: Inside China’s Dystopian Dreams: A.I., Shame and Lots of Cameras
articles.snippet: Beijing is putting billions of dollars behind facial recognition and other technologies to track and control its citizens.
articles.abstract: Beijing is putting billions of dollars behind facial recognition and other technologies to track and control its citizens.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZHENGZHOU, China — In the Chinese city of Zhengzhou, a police officer wearing facial recognition glasses spotted a heroin smuggler at a train station.

articles.headline: HBO Must Get Bigger and Broader, Says Its New Overseer
articles.snippet: “It’s going to be a tough year,” the AT&T veteran John Stankey said in a candid talk with HBO’s chief executive, Richard Plepler, and network employees.
articles.abstract: “It’s going to be a tough year,” the AT&T veteran John Stankey said in a candid talk with HBO’s chief executive, Richard Plepler, and network employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: Change is coming to HBO, now that it is part of the AT&T corporate family. That much was clear to the 150 employees who attended a recent town hall meeting at the network’s headquarters in Midtown Manhattan.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee and John Koblin

articles.headline: Martin Sorrell Is Gone From WPP, but That Doesn’t Mean He’s Gone Quiet
articles.snippet: Mr. Sorrell, who reigned at the advertising conglomerate for more than three decades before being pushed out, has created a new company and is bidding against WPP for a Dutch marketing firm.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sorrell, who reigned at the advertising conglomerate for more than three decades before being pushed out, has created a new company and is bidding against WPP for a Dutch marketing firm.
articles.lead_paragraph: Martin Sorrell reigned as one of the most influential leaders in the advertising industry for three decades as the chief executive of the marketing colossus WPP. After he abruptly resigned in April following an investigation into alleged personal misconduct, the normally sharp-tongued, frenetic 73-year-old slipped unexpectedly out of sight.

articles.headline: Sorry, Power-Lunchers. This Restaurant Is a Co-Working Space Now.
articles.snippet: Everything, it seems, is a shared office these days, including upscale dining rooms before they open for the evening. A start-up called Spacious is driving the trend.
articles.abstract: Everything, it seems, is a shared office these days, including upscale dining rooms before they open for the evening. A start-up called Spacious is driving the trend.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The bar at the Elite Cafe here was packed, but not a drink was being poured. The champagne stand sat empty and warm. The tap was covered in plastic wrap.

articles.headline: Government Work Done, Tax Policy Writers Decamp to Lobbying Jobs
articles.snippet: As businesses scramble to navigate the new tax law, they are recruiting the people who wrote it to help look for loopholes. More than a dozen people have moved on.
articles.abstract: As businesses scramble to navigate the new tax law, they are recruiting the people who wrote it to help look for loopholes. More than a dozen people have moved on.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Six months after Republicans pushed a $1.5 trillion tax overhaul through Congress, many of the most influential players who worked behind the scenes on the legislation are no longer on Capitol Hill or in the Trump administration.

articles.headline: In Daring Underwater Cave Rescue, 4 of 13 Thai Are Freed
articles.snippet: One by one, the first four members of a youth soccer team to be rescued emerged after a perilous, hourslong swim through tight passageways.
articles.abstract: One by one, the first four members of a youth soccer team to be rescued emerged after a perilous, hourslong swim through tight passageways.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAE SAI, Thailand — When the wail of the ambulance siren first reached the Thai village, people started cheering: The sound meant one of the boys trapped in a cave for more than two weeks was out at last and on his way to the hospital.
articles.byline: By Richard C. Paddock and Hannah Beech

articles.headline: Xiaomi’s Weak I.P.O. Raises Doubts About China’s Tech Boom
articles.snippet: Investors were skeptical over the smartphone maker’s plans. Bigger offerings in coming months could show whether broader concerns were also a factor.
articles.abstract: Investors were skeptical over the smartphone maker’s plans. Bigger offerings in coming months could show whether broader concerns were also a factor.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Xiaomi’s public debut was supposed to value the Chinese gadget maker at $100 billion and set the stage for a global coming-out party for some of China’s most successful technology companies.

articles.headline: Theresa May in Fight to Save Government Amid Brexit Rift
articles.snippet: Boris Johnson, the foreign secretary, quit to protest Mrs. May’s Brexit approach, deepening divisions in the British government.
articles.abstract: Boris Johnson, the foreign secretary, quit to protest Mrs. May’s Brexit approach, deepening divisions in the British government.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain was battling to save her government on Monday after her foreign secretary quit in protest over her approach to withdrawing from the European Union. The resignation deepened a mood of crisis just eight months before the country is due to leave the bloc.

articles.headline: In Texas, a Decades-Old Hate Crime, Forgiven but Never Forgotten
articles.snippet: The family of James Byrd Jr., a Texas man dragged to his death 20 years ago, is working to preserve the memory of a racially motivated killing that shocked the nation.
articles.abstract: The family of James Byrd Jr., a Texas man dragged to his death 20 years ago, is working to preserve the memory of a racially motivated killing that shocked the nation.
articles.lead_paragraph: [For more coverage of race, sign up here to have our Race/Related newsletter delivered weekly to your inbox.]

articles.headline: China’s Taste for Soybeans Is a Weak Spot in the Trade War With Trump
articles.snippet: Beijing’s retaliatory tariffs make American soy pricier. But the country’s huge demand for oil and animal feed makes it tough to stop importing overnight.
articles.abstract: Beijing’s retaliatory tariffs make American soy pricier. But the country’s huge demand for oil and animal feed makes it tough to stop importing overnight.
articles.lead_paragraph: XIAOWUSILI, China — For all its economic might, China hasn’t been able to solve a crucial problem.
